sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using inverse matrices
message_1:
Find the solution to the following system of linear equations using inverse matrices:

$x+2y+3z = 6$

$2x+5y+2z = 4$

$6x-3y+z=2$
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using inverse matrices, we first need to write the given system in the matrix form AX = B, where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the matrix of variables, and B is the matrix of constants.

The given system can be written as:

$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 5 & 2 \\ 6 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, $X = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}$, and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$.

Now, we need to find the inverse of matrix A, denoted as $A^{-1}$. To do this, we first find the determinant of A:

$|A| = 1(5 \cdot 1 - 2 \cdot -3) - 2(2 \cdot 1 - 2 \cdot -3) + 3(2 \cdot -3 - 5 \cdot 6)$
$|A| = 1(5 + 6) - 2(2 + 6) + 3(-6 - 30)$
$|A| = 11 - 2(8) - 108$
$|A| = 11 - 16 + 108$
$|A| = 103$

Since the determinant is non-zero, the inverse of A exists. Now, we find the adjugate of A and then divide each element by the determinant to get the inverse.

The adjugate of A is:

$adj(A) = \begin{bmatrix} -15 & -2 & 10 \\ 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 9 & 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, we find the inverse of A:

$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{|A|} \cdot adj(A) = \frac{1}{103} \begin{bmatrix} -15 & -2 & 10 \\ 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 9 & 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, we can find the solution matrix X by multiplying the inverse of A with B:

$X = A^{-1}B = \frac{1}{103} \begin{bmatrix} -15 & -2 & 10 \\ 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 9 & 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

$X = \frac{1}{103} \begin{bmatrix} -60 \\ 0 \\ 52 \end{bmatrix}$

$X = \begin{bmatrix} -60/103 \\ 0 \\ 52/103 \end{bmatrix}$

So, the solution to the given system of linear equations is:

$x = -\frac{60}{103}$, $y = 0$, and $z = \frac{52}{103}$.
